Hello there! Let\'s begin with a story
In the year 1854, London, the capital city of England, experienced an outbreak of Cholera.
The sad thing was, no one really knew what Cholrea was or how to go about treating it.
It was considered that such diseases spread through the air while it really was a water-borne disease.
At that time, John Snow, a young British doctor did not really buy the idea of Cholera spreading through the air. He started looking around.
He tracked down information from hospital and public records on when the outbreak began and tried to see what was common to the victims.
He put out all the information collected onto a map of London.

Several interesting facts came to light by looking at this colored map. Blocks near Broad street seemed to be heavily affected while neighboring blocks, just a mile or so away, seemed to be totally unaffected.
What was going on?
On talking to people living there,John discovered that people in the nearby unaffected blocks used a different hand pump to fetch water than those living near Broad street.
This helped John rule out other possible sources of the epidemic besides pump water.
On 7 September 1854, Snow took his research to the town officials and convinced them to take the handle off the pump, making it impossible to draw water.
The officials were reluctant to believe him, but took the handle off as a trial only to find the outbreak of cholera trickle to a stop.
Gradually, people who had left their homes and businesses in the Broad Street area out of fear of Cholera began to return.
What John Snow did in this example is what data science actually is!
Data Science is learning new things about our world by collecting and analyzing information of events that have taken place.
In this example, John Snow showed how relating data on people’s source of water to the places they lives was able to show possibly infected hand pumps.
